items.title: Distinguishing the flow of airborne microorganisms along with environmental conditions and their influence on historic heritage buildings
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 06 August 2025

Distinguishing the flow of airborne microorganisms along with environmental conditions and their influence on historic heritage buildings
                    L. de-Lemos-Medina 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-3795-73541,2, A. Bermúdez-Marín3, D. Jaikel-Víquez 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-3553-53934,5,6, N. Camacho-Cambronero4, A. Segura-Vargas4, A. Gómez-Arrieta4, Y. Mora-Quirós5, K. Ureña-Alvarado7, L. Rautenberg8, I. Fonseca-Alfaro9,10, P. Calderón-Mesén5,11, M. Sandoval-Gutiérrez12, M. Redondo-Solano4,6,13 & …O. A. Herrera-Sancho 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-8871-171X5,9,10,14 Show authors

Scientific Reports

volume 15, Article number: 28750 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Air microbiologyCharacterization and analytical techniquesEnvironmental healthEnvironmental impactEnvironmental monitoring

AbstractThe National Theater of Costa Rica is a national symbol of our country and an important architectural landmark. It was built in 1897 and is decorated with large-format paintings made by Italian artists. One of these painters was Paolo Serra, who was in charge of decorating three chambers, including the Management’s Office (MO). A yearly volumetric air sampling was conducted in seven rooms of the theater, showing high levels of circulating fungal spores in the MO. Thus, further analysis was carried out in this venue. First, the environmental conditions (wind velocity, temperature, relative humidity, and particles) were monitored. Then, the air and particles’ flow and the probability of particles concentration were simulated for different scenarios of natural ventilation using a Discrete Phase Model. This allowed us to identify areas where damage and microorganisms were probably more prevalent. The artworks in this chamber were analyzed to determine the types of damages identified: buckling, cracks, cuts, craquelure, holes, scratches, color gaps with exposed fabric or wall, insect debris, flaking, humidity stains, interventions of old restorations, opaque stains, whitish stains and total loss of the original image. As a complement, a microbiological sample was held in 34 sites of interest, resulting in the isolation and identification of five bacterial isolates and thirteen fungi. We identified the artist’s main colour palette: madder lake, lead white, calcium carbonate, yellow ocher, natural ultramarine and natural barite. We can conclude that artworks under non-controlled environmental conditions may present a significant degree of deterioration, biodeterioration, and chromatic alteration.

IntroductionCultural historical buildings represent a form of expression which frames certain feelings and describes the social and economical state of societies within a given moment. It is necessary to preserve these constructions for the next generation because of their great historical value, which allows us to understand various aspects of societies, such as their history and development. These cultural heritage conservation processes are supported by a series of problem-solving perspectives and tools that allow the identification of materials and considerations from the point of view of technique and technology used by artists for their intentions and creative process1,2,3,4,5. Little is known about the environmental impact of geographical location on heritage buildings, especially of those located in tropical countries, along with the intention of its construction and it is not clear what factors represent a key challenge to ensure the conservation of the artworks in these atmospheres.Therefore, this pilot study seeks to remedy these challenges by analyzing the environmental conditions of the Management’s Office (MO) of the National Theater of Costa Rica (NTCR [built in 1891-1897]) and to determine their impact on the large-format paintings located within this chamber (see Fig. 1 for our artistic visualization). The NTCR is a historical building that represents society’s desire to experience various expressions of art locally, like other theaters’ intent throughout Europe and Latin America6. In this building, the south and east sides are lined with typically busy streets (pedestrians and vehicles), while the north and west sides have a plaza where many pigeons live and where people pass through all day long. The MO is located in the southwest corner of the building (Fig. 2) and is decorated with wall-to-wall murals and a large-format oil painting on the ceiling, all painted by Italian artist Paolo Serra. Environmental conditions play an important role in the maintenance of these historic buildings, especially those that shelter important artworks that are exposed to climate changes and different conditions since the time of its construction7,8. Therefore, environmental conditions could be a major factor, causing degradation damage to historic heritage if there are no climatized systems that keep the temperature and relative humidity under control, independently of the external conditions. Another important practical implication is that when the historic buildings are open to the public, there are greater probabilities that the temperature, humidity, airborne microorganisms, internal microclimate, and the energy performance of the entire system will vary8.To a limited extent, three methods have been identified as being potentially important for keeping the internal environmental conditions of historic buildings under control: (1) natural ventilation, (2) forced ventilation and (3) air conditioning. Most historic buildings were designed and built using natural ventilation (1), accordingly, it is an additional challenge to make modifications that allow the inclusion of any of the other types of techniques, namely (2) and (3), especially in those that contain cultural heritage without causing structural harm or several major drawbacks to the artworks9. It has been shown that there is an unambiguous relationship between temperature variations and paintings, specifically thermal fatigue could be generated, which has possible connections to the artworks’ damages10. It is worth mentioning that the NTCR only has an air conditioning system in the main chamber, yet the rest of the rooms do not have controlled environmental conditions. The MO chamber has three large windows that are periodically opened. The artworks are not exposed to the public, except for special visitors with controlled access, including diplomats, researchers, conservators, restorers, and visitors by appointment or formal invitation. The access door to this room is located on the north side, next to the main entrance of the building. Once inside, one can appreciate the large format paintings that delicately decorate all the walls and ceiling of the chamber. The study’s objective was to examine these large-format paintings exhibited under non-controlled environmental conditions from an interdisciplinary viewpoint for evidence findings that methodically assess the conservation state, i.e. the deterioration and biodeterioration, chromatic alteration, and the artist’s color palette (Fig. 1). Finally, our aim is therefore to provide a systematic correlation between these parameters and deterioration that can be identified in the artworks. It is worth mentioning that in previous works at the NTCR, we observed a new fungal species associated with damaging cultural heritage11: we distinguished particular fluorescent areas which were recognized through its red-coral fluorescence as Madder Lake12, we identified Carlo Ferrario’s main colour palette, along with we successfully achieved the characterization of eight genera of calcareous nannofossils found in the ground layers of his artwork13. Carlo Ferrario was an Italian artist, who was commissioned to paint Musas I and Musas II, two of the most important and representative paintings of the NTCR. However, our goal of having a deeper understanding of the inexorable complexity which surrounds the artwork’s habitat, colour modification suitable to environmental adaptation, and the pictorial materials used by artists from respective epochs to devise a historic building that has remained elusive.Fig. 1Multidisciplinary approach to the study of the effect of environmental conditions on the artworks found in the Management’s Office of the National Theater of Costa Rica. This study aims to describe how temperature, relative humidity, air flow and microbial colonization have deteriorated the murals, and the ceiling painted by the Italian artist Paolo Serra. The room is decorated with Pompeian inspired art and is located at the entrance of the theater, in the southwest corner. As shown in the illustration, it has three windows facing the outside environment where air, light and diverse microorganisms can enter the venue. Evelyn María Zamora Conejo partially created the figure. The figure was created by the authors following what is described in the Supplementary Information and using the following computer tools: Adobe Illustrator, version number 27.1 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/illustrator.html) and Adobe Photoshop, version number 23.3.2 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/photoshop.html).Full size imageFig. 2Location of the Management Office (MO) of the National Theater of Costa Rica (NTCR). (A) The MO is located in the southwest corner of the NTCR, bordered to the south by one of the Capitals’ main streets, and a plaza, filled with pigeons and pedestrians, to the west. (B) The room has three windows that are usually open throughout the week and a door that leads to the theater’s entrance hallway. As shown in the panel (C), the room is completely decorated with paintings by Italian artist Paolo Serra, in a clear Pompeian style. The figure was created by the authors following what is described in the Supplementary Information and using the following computer tools: Adobe Illustrator, version number 27.1 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/illustrator.html) and Adobe Photoshop, version number 23.3.2 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/photoshop.html).Full size imagePaolo SerraPaolo Serra was an Italian painter trained at the academies of Naples and Florence. Later, he worked as a teacher at the Academy of Rome. After that, he traveled to Costa Rica to fulfill a contract that entrusted him with painting part of the decorative artworks of the NTCR. Upon completing these paintings, he settled permanently in the country where he carried out other commissions, such as the paintings for the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Heredia, the old Casa Cural of the Villa de Barva in Heredia, and the Chapel of the Hospicio Carlos María Ulloa. Unfortunately, out of these three places, only the painting of Hospicio has survived14,15.Serra’s style was distinguished by its dynamism, intense chromaticism, and a clear influence by Pompeian murals. He used to decorate his paintings with decorative borders, frequently using repeated motifs that he may have executed using molds. There are variations in the painter’s signatures: in some of the works at the NTCR, he signed as Paolo, while in others he used the name Pablo. This could be due to an adaptation to the Latin American context of the time or, perhaps, to the fact that one of his assistants signed on his behalf, a common practice at that time. For this research, two types of artworks were analyzed: oil on canvas attached to the ceiling and a mural on the west elevation composed of four paintings to complete the chamber known as MO. Both artworks were produced in 1897 by Paolo Serra (1860-1900), as part of the construction of the NTCR. In addition to the mural paintings at the NTCR, a few easel works are known, such as landscapes, still life, and portraits, which are currently part of private collections. Paolo Serra died on December 9, 1900, in the city of Heredia at the age of 40.Results and discussionIdentification of deteriorations in the artworks under studyPhotographs in the visible (VIS) and ultraviolet (UV) spectrum were generated for each of the paintings studied. Examples of these pictures are presented in Figs. 2B, 5, and 6. Based on the analysis of the photographs and ocular inspection carried out in situ at the NTCR, several damages and significant deterioration were identified. As a guide to determine the type of damage the following bibliography was consulted: Australian Institute for the Conservation of Cultural Material Inc (AICCM)16, Mayorga17 and Calvo18. Supplementary Table 2 shows the definition and general characterization of these deteriorations found and Table 1 presents the identification number, name and percentage of damage, and the quadrants in which each is presented in the painting of the MO ceiling. For example, cracks were identified in all the quadrants. The damages are also illustrated with an image of the actual damage found in each of the artworks in question and their location according to the previously established grid. Fig. 5B illustrates the damages found in the painting of the ceiling. It is worth mentioning that, as an example of the identification of the damages, a zoom of the grid number 28 is presented, which has many damages identified by different colors: cracking, cracks, excrement of insects, opaque spots, exposed support, holes, and scratches.Table 1 Table of damages by quadrant on Management Office ceiling (Danthe y Rafael).Full size tableAerial microorganisms contamination of the NTCRThe fungal aerial concentration of seven rooms of the NTCR (i.e. Hall next to the Ladies’ Cafeteria, Men’s Canteen, Hall next to the Men’s Canteen, MO, Smoking Lounge for Ladies, Smoking Lounge for Men, and the Presidential Theater Box, see Supplementary Figure S1) was determined throughout the year 2022. As described in the Methods section, one monthly sampling was carried out, except for June and December for reasons beyond the control of the study. In June, Hurricane Bonnie prevented visitors from entering the facility, and in December the NTCR was closed for the holiday season. Therefore, the results reflect data collected during the ten months of the year under study.Table 2 shows the fungal aerial concentration by cubic meter of the seven rooms sampled. The highest mean concentration was found in the Hall attached to the Ladies’ Cafeteria (1355 ± 459 spores/m³) and the lowest in the Smoking Lounge for Ladies (701 ± 275 spores/m³). However, the NTCR MO presented the highest concentration of all the samplings during April (4408 spores/m³). This was the month that presented the highest mean fungal concentration (1610 ± 1368 spores/m³), while July was the lowest (548 ± 174 spores/m³). Significant statistical differences were found between the fungal aerial concentration of each month (F = 2.264; df = 9; p = 0.03). The data was divided into three groups: the first group included the months of March and July, the second group January, February, May, August, September, October, and November; and only April in the third group. This indicates that the months with lower concentrations (March and July) presented significant differences respect to the other months of the year, which in turn, showed significant differences compared to April, the month with the highest concentration. It is worth noting that the high fungal concentrations found in April are due to the levels found in the NTCR’s MO. In Fig. 3A, the boxplot graphic of the monthly measurements of the fungal aerial concentration of all the rooms sampled is presented and includes specifically the value of Cladosporium spp. fungal spore concentration since this is presented in the biggest amount, so that is the most representative. It is worth mentioning that similar results have been documented for other indoor environments in Costa Rica. In a study conducted inside three schools located in the Province of Heredia, high fungal aerial concentrations were reported during the months of May and October (rainy season, ranging from 3194 to 3747 spores/m³) and the lowest on March (1392 ± 120 spores/m³). Once again, the main fungal spore identified belonged to the genus Cladosporium19. On the other hand, a study analyzing the fungal aerial concentration of the outside environment of an academic institution found much lower concentrations with a yearly mean of 444 ± 202 spores/m³. Eighteen types of spores were identified, the majority of which were sexual spores20. These results exemplify the importance of ventilation of enclosed spaces, since a lack of ventilation could result in a concentration of spores.Table 2 Fungal aerial concentration of seven rooms of the Costa Rican National Theater (TNCR), during 2022.Full size tableFig. 3Aerial microbiological contamination of the Management Office (MO) of the National Theater of Costa Rica (NTCR).  (A) Graphic shows in light blue, the quartiles of the monthly aerial microbiological spore concentration of seven chambers within the NTCR that was determined throughout the year 2022, being Cladosporium’s spores, represented by the red square dot the most frequently found in the theater’s air. During October 2023, further analyses were carried out in the MO (B), involving active and passive aerial studies. Seventeen sampling sites were chosen including measurements at ground level and different heights (1.3 m and 2.6 m from the floor). Colour scales are used to represent the distribution of microbial contamination found. (C) Cladosporium’s spores were the most frequently found. The figure was created by the authors following what is described in the Supplementary Information and using the following computer tools: Adobe Illustrator, version number 27.1 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/illustrator.html) and Adobe Photoshop, version number 23.3.2 (https://www.adobe.com/la/products/photoshop.html).Full size imageThe high concentration of fungal spores per cubic meter found during 2022 in the MO is a matter of concern, given that it is a space actively used by different NTCR’s personnel who are thus, being exposed to fungal antigens and spores for prolonged periods of time. This is relevant because there is a correlation between high spore concentrations and occupational risk in asthmatic workers and those allergic to Penicillium and/or Alternaria alternata21. It is worth noting that Penicillium is one of the main genera of fungi found throughout the NTCR’s air and walls22. Additionally, the entire enclosure in which Serra’s artworks are located could be bio deteriorated by these fungi. The latter happens because paintings are made of different materials composed of organic and inorganic molecules, which under the right environmental conditions, can lead to the colonization of a wide variety of microorganisms that cause both aesthetic and structural deterioration23. Therefore, additional experiments were carried out to evaluate the fungal and bacterial contamination of this chamber. Seventeen sampling sites were selected for passive and active air samplings (see Fig. 3B) and 34 for microbiological isolation (ten from the murals and 24 from the ceiling) (see Fig. 5B).Aerial contamination of the MODue to the high fungal aerial concentration found in the MO during the 2022 campaign, additional experiments were carried out to evaluate the fungal and bacterial contamination of this chamber (refer to Methods section Microbial Contamination of the MO). Seventeen sampling sites were selected for passive and active air monitoring in this room (see Fig. 3B). The results of these sampling are presented in Table 3.Table 3 Passive and active air sampling of the Management’s Office.Full size tableAs seen in Table 3, the north side and southeast corner were the places within the MO with the highest concentrations of both fungi and bacteria. There are two factors that can explain the high concentration of microorganisms in these areas. Firstly, this chamber has a window facing one of the busiest streets in terms of traffic and pedestrians in the province of San José (“Avenida Segunda”, in Spanish) and another one facing the Culture Place (“Plaza de la Cultura”, in Spanish). Thus, the highest concentration of microorganisms was found close to these windows, coinciding with the way the air circulates inside the chamber. It is worth noting that a correlation between exposure to environmental pollution with increase in spore concentration has been documented; also, temperature increases during the dry season relate to increasing human activities that cause pollution24. This could explain the fact that April was the month with the highest concentration, as it coincides with the dry season in Costa Rica. Another finding that supports this hypothesis is the high concentration of ascospores and basidiospores (Supplementary Table 1). These fungi have been described as the dominant biological particles in aerobiological studies of tropical areas, which are dispersed through the air and whose dispersion is dependent on humidity25. Basidiomycetes, for example, are part of various organic cycles degrading substrates such as cellulose and lignin, which are also components of different artistic works. Additionally, Trichaptum abietinum has been described to produce laccase and peroxidase activity, which can decolorate different aromatic dyes used in a wide spectrum of artistic productions26.Furthermore, the second factor that affects the spore aerial concentration is the colonization of walls and ceilings a matter that is being discussed in the following section.Isolation of microorganisms from the murals and ceiling of the MO34 regions of interest (ten from the murals and 24 from the ceiling [see Supplementary Figure 2]), for possible microbial growth, were identified after the analysis of the paintings’ deterioration maps. Six out of the ten sampling sites selected on the murals were positive for microbial growth. Staphylococcus saprophyticus, Cladosporium cladosporioides complex, Yarrowia lipolytica (Candida lipolytica) and a hyaline non-identified fungal isolate were retrieved from the east side of the north wall from a crack with loss of support. Penicillium citrinum and a hyaline non-identified fungi were retrieved from another crack with loss of support from the north side of the west wall. C. cladosporioides and Bacillus cereus were retrieved from opaque stains found in the center and south side of the west wall and Sphingomonas paucimobillis was isolated from the west side of the south wall from an area with discoloration. In regard to the ceiling, C. cladosporioides, Staphylococcus warnerii and Aspergillus section Fumigati were retrieved from the northwest side of the painting and P. citrinum and Aspergillus section Fumigati from the southeast side. They were retrieved from cracks and dark stains. The isolation of microbial agents shows a direct colonization of the surfaces that contributes significantly to the airborne concentration of spores, since the positive sampling areas correspond with the highest aerial concentration of microorganisms. This colonization has also been found in other paintings of the NTCR like Carlo Ferrario’s Musas I and II where Penicillium, Cladosporium and Bacillus were the main agents of biodeterioration identified22.Cladosporium spp. (the most frequently isolated fungi within the NTCR) is also the main biological agent described in biodeterioration processes in wall paintings27. This agent was found in several sampling sites in the MO and in the passive and active aerial studies. The deterioration mechanism described by Savkovic28 and collaborators indicates that the fungus can cause surface deterioration, causing brown discoloration stains, or even deep penetrating the artwork, surpassing the layer of paint and reaching the support. This is achieved through mechanical activities, such as the penetration of hyphae that increases the internal pressure of the painting leading to the formation of cracks. In addition, it causes damage through the chemical activity of extracellular enzymes secreted by the fungus when trying to use paint components as a source of nutrients. A study conducted in Brazil found that spores of Cladosporium cladosporioides and C. spinulosum are also capable of secreting enzymes for cellulose metabolism, which is a finding of special importance for museums with artworks made of wood29.Fungi of the genus Penicillium sp. have also been described in the literature as fungal agents of biodeterioration. It has been shown that Penicillium spores are capable of surviving in indoor environments for long periods of time, in addition to being dry-walled spores, which makes them light and easily dissociable from their reproductive structures30. These characteristics make the spores of this microorganism easily airborne and ideal for colonization of internal spaces such as the NTCR MO. Regarding relevant enzymes in the process of wear and tear of artistic artworks, different enzymes with proteolytic and cellulolytic activity, such as caseases and cellulases, have been found in vitro studies28. These enzymes can degrade numerous common substrates used in the production of artistic artworks, such as silk, wool, adhesives of layers of paint, paper, among others. Savkovic and collaborators also found that several species of Penicillium can excrete exopigments of different colors depending on the environmental conditions in which the fungus is found, which also contributes to the aesthetic degradation of artworks. One of the conditions that can favor the formation of these pigments is the availability of carbon, which could be found in high concentrations in this NTCR enclosure due to the external contamination to which it is exposed that was mentioned above.As for the bacteria, the highest number of isolates obtained from both the walls and the ceiling, were of the genus Staphylococcus. The members of the genus Staphylococcus are Gram-positive cocci that produce biofilms (polysaccharide matrixes) which allow them to adhere to many different surfaces31, in this case paintings. S. paucimobilis is a Gram-negative rod-shaped bacterium found in soil, aquatic and hospital environments. It produces a yellow pigment and is mobile through flagelli32. Finally, B. cereus is a Gram-positive rod also commonly found in soil and food. It is worth mentioning that it produces spores that are resistant to adverse environmental conditions, such as extreme temperatures, different pHs and low humidity33. This adaptation has allowed it to be a bacterium usually found colonizing the paintings of the NTCR22. Although the impairment implications of bacterial agents have not been studied as extensively as fungal agents, they have been found to possess similar enzymes such as proteases, esterases, and lipases34, plus the virulence factors previously described, which help these organisms degrade and discolor pigments frequently used in the elaboration of paintings and murals, such as black, red, and yellow ochre, among others.Atmospheric measurements in the MO at the NTCRMeasuring and monitoring temperature and relative humidity is necessary in historical and heritage buildings, along with other parameters like physical agents or light are highly recommended35,36. Natural ventilation from the windows of the MO is the mechanism mostly used in the NTCR, according to the information given by the personnel. From the observed data on wind velocity, temperature, and relative humidity at various points in the room, it was found that there were minimal variations when the windows were closed but slightly more when some of the windows were open. This is expected, as the airflow in the room was very low, as indicated by the air flow speed measurements. Nevertheless, when one of the windows or both windows were open, the values of wind speed, temperature and relative humidity changes as can be seen in Fig. 4A and Supplementary Figure S3. For the wind speed measurements, with the windows closed, the local wind velocity in the room averaged is about 0.06 m/s, with a standard deviation of 0.01 m/s. The last column includes the main elements for every type of pigment.Full size tableConclusionsThese research aimed to examine for the first time Serra’s paintings under non-controlled environmental conditions in a historic heritage building. It methodically assesses the deterioration, biodeterioration, and chromatic alteration, along with the artist’s color palette. One of the most significant outcomes of this cutting-edge multidisciplinary research, assembled by our fluid simulation using solid particle dynamics in the environment chamber along with experimental data of wind speed, temperature, and particle size, among others, was the recognition of specific zones, at the artworks, which could be affected by their visual appearance over the time since the painting’s creation. The second major finding to emerge was that following the regions of interest previously obtained, we identified a considerable amount of deterioration patterns, biodeterioration microorganisms, and degradation of colour in the paintings. This finding has important suggestions for establishing affordable, compact, efficient, accessible, and novel non-destructive techniques, especially in the extreme climate and humidity of the tropics in Latin America in historic heritage buildings. The third significant finding of this investigation was that in an exploratory experiment we recognized the main artist’s colour palette, which includes: madder lake, lead white, calcium carbonate, yellow ocher, natural ultramarine, and natural barite. For fine finishing, a EcoMet 30 Buehler®polisher was used, for two 15-min cycles with 15 \(\mu\)m and 3 \(\mu\)m alumina abrasive (Allied High-Tech Products®), under the following conditions: 150 rpm for stage and 150 rpm and 30 N force for the support arm, which rotated opposite to the stage. A DX.2053-PLPOLRi Delphi-X Observer microscope was used, as well as an equipped DC.18000-Pro Euromex digital camera along with a DT 1000 CE UV/VIS AIS light source was employed with a SR fiber type with a 600 \(\mu\)m core diameter (please see Fig. 6A). To obtain the complete view of the sample, a composition of 108 photos using Adobe Photoshop® was made, since the 20x magnitication allowed an aproppriate view of the sample but took small regions only; therefore, a composition of layers and a panorama had to be made (please see Fig. 6A.2). To avoid scale problems through this manipulation of the photos, the correct scale bar was included at the end, considering the longitude of the sample from two points and getting the reference from the SEM analysis, using the software ImageJ 1.54g. The latter to determine the pigment crystal distribution as shown in Table 5.Scanning electron microscope – energy dispersive X-Ray spectroscopy (SEM–EDX)The samples were analyzed to determine their microstructure and elemental composition. Initially, they were examined using a stereoscope for macro photography. For microanalysis, each sample was mounted on a metal base and secured with double-sided carbon tape. Subsequently, the fragments were analyzed in a JEOL JSM-IT 500 scanning electron microscope under variable pressure, utilizing backscattered electron imaging to assess their structural characteristics. The SEM is equipped with a corresponding EDX detector, which facilitates elemental analysis of different areas of the sample, as well as specific crystals within cross sections.

Machine learning analysis of greenhouse gas sources impacting Africa’s food security nexus
items.body:

Machine learning analysis of greenhouse gas sources impacting Africa’s food security nexus
                    Adusei Bofa1 & Temesgen Zewotir2

Scientific Reports

volume 15, Article number: 28665 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            AttributionEnvironmental impact

AbstractThe essential need to identify the most informative sources of greenhouse gas emissions (climate change drivers) impacting the food security nexus in Africa requires a comprehensive and holistic approach. Machine learning method excels in the identification of single-variable importance, our study complements their abilities by deriving principal components using principal component analysis (PCA) to give a significant understanding of the three primary greenhouse gases (carbon dioxide (CO₂), methane (CH₄), and nitrous oxide (N₂O)). We used data from FAO concerning Africa from 2000 to 2021. Food household consumption emission (CH₄), burning crop residues (N₂O), and food transport (N₂O) are the key variables identified by machine learning as critical contributors to climate change drivers impacting food security. Biomass-burning emissions factor, land management emissions factor, and food supply chain emissions factor are the key principal components after subjecting the 86 to PCA. Focusing on the variables and the factors revealed by the extreme gradient, random forest, and PCA can help stakeholders develop efficient practices like promoting sustainable crop residue management and a sustainable food system that reduces post-harvest loss. Our study did not consider the potential impact of spatial effect in the identification of the key sources of greenhouse gases impacting food security, we will explore this in future works.

                        IntroductionIn Africa, several individuals suffering from food insecurity and malnutrition have severely impacted health education and economic growth making people more susceptible to food insecurity. Increasing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions has also negatively increased the climate variability concerning agricultural produce, leading to the attraction of researchers to investigate the relationship between climate change and food insecurity1. Even though the climate of the earth has been changing for the past millions of years current indicator indicates a rapidly changing rate and researchers are in agreement it is due to human activities2,3. These human activities have led to heatwaves, heavy rains, and protracted droughts as a result of greenhouse gases(drivers of climate change) emissions such as carbon dioxide (CO₂), methane (CH₄), and nitrous oxide (N₂O)4. In particular, the human activities associated with industrial growth and agriculture practices are the major contributors to these emissions in Africa5.The rising food security has been associated with climate-related factors globally6. The four main pillars(accessibility, availability, utilization, and stability ) of food security as specified by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) are significantly affected by CO₂, CH₄, and N₂O7 This is apparent in the impact of extreme weather events affecting several facets of livelihoods such degrade the nutritional value of crops, health, and food security2. Adesete, Olanubi8 support this by highlighting the difficulties associated with achieving the four primary pillars of food security due to environmental complications. Africa may be more susceptible to food security due to substantial dependence on climate-sensitive agricultural systems and low ability to adjust to climatic shocks9,10. Africa’s already limited natural and environmental resources are under tremendous strain due to climate change. Food instability, widespread undernourishment, malnutrition, frequent maternal mortality, and dietary inadequacies are among the ongoing issues caused by the enormous strain on forests, land, water, air, biodiversity, and ecosystem services8.Although numerous studies6,11,12 have investigated the effects of climate change on the food and agricultural sectors, other literature13,14 have investigated the effects of climate change on the food and agricultural sectors, other literature. In order to attain all four pillars (availability, accessibility, utilization, and stability), it is necessary to investigate the specific greenhouse gas sources that influence food insecurity. In the context of Africa, this area remains underexplored, to the best of our knowledge.Researchers15,16 can identify important factors of food insecurity by using machine learning to reveal intricate correlations within large datasets. Machine learning makes it possible to mine several complex correlations existing within the data17, this makes it convenient for identifying the most informative source for greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions concerning Africa’s food security. In the presence of multicollinearity, Machine learning methods fail to capture significant underlying structures within the data despite their ability to prioritize variables effectively18. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) creates variables that combine the related variable impact to explain the significant variation within the data based on a statistical learning framework19. Hence, we combine machine learning and PCA (statistical learning) to identify the most informative source of climate change drivers (CO₂, CH₄, and N₂O) concerning Africa’s food security.According to the literature20, which assessed 91 studies, research on food security has mostly concentrated on household levels, frequently ignoring regional perspectives in the context of Africa and lacking statistical modeling. To tackle this issue, Bofa and Zewotir21 created elements that cover each of the four pillars of food security within the African setting. However, climate-related variables were not taken into account in their studies. According to recent estimates, the global food system is responsible for almost one-third of greenhouse gas emissions8,22,23.To achieve Sustainable Development Goals, especially in the African context it is essential to identify the significant sources of CO₂, CH₄, and N₂O to facilitate efficient solutions to guarantee public health safety for a better grasp of the connections between climate change and food security. It is also vital to develop and incorporate composite factors that integrate the main sources of greenhouse gas (CO₂, CH₄, and N₂O)24 to broadly understand their collective influence on food security in Africa using statistical learning. We apply machine learning and PCA to identify the main sources of greenhouse gas emissions associated with food security in Africa as the selection of food security indicators has relied on subjective judgment20 by experts rather than a statistical learning framework.Complementing machine learning models with PCA provides an advantage to the challenges associated with complex and high-dimensional datasets. Using variable importance, the machine learning models identify key sources of CO₂, CH₄, and N₂O (greenhouse gas) about food security whereas the PCA accounts for a significant variation within the complete data by linking related components to capture wider trends. This is essential for policymakers and stakeholders to enable targeted actions such as incentivizing sustainable practices for key variables(sources) and sharing data and strategies among African countries to curb the emission of greenhouse gases. Again, this procedure can be applied to other areas which may include epidemiology, healthcare, and finance where similar high-dimensional data challenges may arise.Data and statistical methodsA key component in assessing the sources of greenhouse gases in connection with food security concerning Africa is a reliable data source. Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) plays an essential role in the provision of data for global food and agriculture dynamics. This research utilized data from the FAO, including meta-information, covering the period from 2000 to 2021 for Africa, resulting in a total of 1187 observations available at https://www.fao.org/faostat/en/#data/GT (Retrieved in November 2024). As evidenced by earlier research25,26,27 our data comprised 86 variables that represented the sources of greenhouse gases for methane (CH₄), nitrous oxide (N₂O), and carbon dioxide (CO₂) as drivers of climate change. As indicated in Table S1, the 86 variables were given specific names to simplify the analysis. The methodology is summarized in Fig. 1, and the variables (sources) and their designated names are included in Table S1. A valuable metric for assessing food security is the frequency of persons who are in the severe food insecurity category28. When individuals are experiencing hunger and are at serious risk of running out of food, in most extreme cases going days without eating, then severe food insecurity has occurred28. Hence the explanatory variable for this study is the number of individuals who are severely food insecure in Africa.Fig. 1Data description and preprocessing workflow for the identification of key sources of greenhouse gases in Africa. By using the expectation-maximization with the bootstrapping procedure to each of the m (the number of imputations) bootstrap samples, this method creates several credible datasets for additional analysis. Across the bootstrap samples, the m estimates of means and variances will differ. Using regression, the first set of estimates is used to impute the first set of missing values first, then the second set of estimates for the second set of missing values, and so this process continues. As a result of this procedure, several imputed datasets are produced, which capture the uncertainty and variability of the missing data. Making it an exceptionally versatile tool for managing complex data structures30,31. A total of 10 imputed datasets were created to address missing data, aligning with the commonly recommended range of 5 to 10 imputations for moderate levels of missingness. Using bootstrapping decision trees are separately trained using several training subsets. The outputs of each tree are averaged to produce the final prediction. The mean decrease in accuracy metric is used to determine the variable importance34,35.Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) is an advanced boosting algorithm that sequentially constructs trees, fixing errors from earlier trees utilizing regularization (LASSO or Ridge) to avoid overfitting. The model initiates by making a simple prediction concerning the mean outcome for a weak model. Then new trees are trained iteratively based on the previous model to minimize the residual errors36.For the Gradient Boosting Machines (GBM) approach, weak learners (decision trees) gradually minimize the residual error associated with the previous. This is achieved by the combination of weak learners with strong learners to improve prediction accuracy. The degree to which each variable raises the accuracy of the model determines its relative importance35,37.The Support Vector Machine (SVM) algorithm selects a suitable kernel function (Linear, Polynomial, or Radial Basis Function) for the impute space transformation after scaling to standardize variables. It then constructs an optimal hyperplane that minimizes error in the regression tasks35,38,39.K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) assigns predictions based on a distance-based algorithm using similarities between data points after normalizing features to ensure fair distance calculations. With cross-validation, the optimal number of neighbors (K) is determined. The target point’s Euclidean distance from its closest neighbors is calculated for predictions. The final estimate(prediction) is determined by averaging the values of the neighbors40.Concerning Neural Network (NN) the input, hidden, and output layers make up the network’s structure, and each neuron uses an activation function like Sigmoid. Backpropagation is used to modify the weights after they are randomly allocated. Optimization algorithms such as gradient descent are then used to determine and minimize the error41.Using the most informative features the Decision Tree (DT) split the dataset to enable the creation of a hierarchical structure for estimation(prediction). Using the best attribute for data splitting at each node, the tree is constructed, and this continues up until the criterion for stopping (e.g., maximum depth or minimum sample split) is reached. While reducing overfitting, pruning techniques are applied. From root to leaf, the tree is traversed to make predictions42.Model evaluationWe utilised 10-fold cross-validation for effective model validation. After the data was divided into 10 folds the model was trained on 10 − 1 folds and tested on the remaining fold. The process continued 10 times until all folds were used as a test set once to ensure that the model was capable of generalizing for unseen data. During this, the root mean square error (RMSE) and mean absolute error (MAE) were computed as the evaluation metrics. The RMSE is given as$$\:RMSE=\sqrt{\frac{1}{n}}\sum\:_{i=1}^{n}{\left({y}_{i}-{\widehat{y}}_{i}\right)}^{2},$$MAE denoted as$$\:MAE=\frac{1}{N}\sum\:_{i}^{N}\left|{y}_{i}-{\widehat{y}}_{i}\right|.$$Where \(\:n\:\)is the number of data points, \(\:{y}_{i}\) is the observed and \(\:{\widehat{y}}_{i}\) represent the predicted values for both RMSE and MAE.Principal component analysisAs a dimensional reduction method for preserving many variations in the data, it begins by standardizing the data to have a mean zero and a standard deviation of one. Then the relationship between variables is captured by the computation of the covariance matrix. Next, the eigenvalues, which measure the variance captured by each principal component, and the eigenvector, which indicates the direction of these components, are computed. The top j eigenvectors are selected to form the principal component as the eigenvalues are sorted in descending order43. Readers are referred to Bofa and Zewotir21 for a detailed mathematical formulation. Using the Pearson correlation coefficient, the principal component that accounts for at least 75% of the variation was named depending on the level of correlation associated with the original dataset44. An absolute value of 0.5 for Pearson’s correlation45 was applied to aid in the naming of significant components. Other notable variables include food supply chain emissions, fire emissions, and land-use change emissions, while there are similarities in the ranking of important variables, slight differences exist in how the models weigh them.DiscussionThe focus of this study was to explore machine learning and statistical learning techniques to identify the key driver (greenhouse gas) of climate change relating to food security. The predictive performance of the seven machine learning models was assessed while the PCA derived a set of components that represent the three main sources (carbon dioxide (CO₂), methane (CH₄), and nitrous oxide (N₂O)) of greenhouse gases46.The extreme gradient boosting model had the lowest RMSE (1.928) and MAE (0.798), with the random forest being the closest (Table 1). This is in line with a previous study that highlighted the superior predictive capabilities of these models in dealing with large data47. These two models exhibited remarkably nearly identical predictive performance with a negligible difference of 0.03 in both RMSE and MAE after cross-validation, underscoring that they are very similar in their predictability concerning the relation in the data. However, since RMSE places slightly greater emphasis on large errors due to its squaring of residuals, the extreme gradient boosting is considered marginally better as it is less likely to produce large prediction errors for food security in Africa. Random forest and extreme gradient boosting can be regarded as strong alternatives for each other as their performance is practically indistinguishable in terms of overall accuracy, making them a viable choice for predictive tasks, with the decision potentially guided by factors like interpretability. This is evident from the paired permutation test33, which showed that the mean differences in performance metrics (MAE and RMSE) between the two models were not statistically significant (p-value = 0.13) at the α = 0.05 level.The first stage of our analysis revealed the 10 most important sources of climate change drivers in Africa from the 86 bulk sources obtained from FAO. They are burning crop residues (N₂O), burning crop residues(CO₂), enteric fermentation(CO₂), manure management (N₂O), synthetic fertilizers(N₂O), food household consumption (CH₄), farm gate(CH₄), land use change (N₂O), Emissions from crop(CO₂), and Land Use, Land Use Change and Forestry LULUCF(CH₄).These 10 sources were reported in previous studies48,49,50,51 as a major cause of climate change resulting in unpredictable weather patterns such as droughts and floods that disrupt crop yields leading to food insecurity.In the second stage, the random forest model outperformed its competing counterpart. The analysis revealed three significant factors, meeting the 75% (first quartile) threshold: biomass-burning emissions, land management emissions, and food supply chain emissions. Biomass burning emissions factor entail fermentation (CO₂ and CH₄), fires in humid tropical forests (CO₂), food retail (CO₂), farm gate (CO₂), land use change (N₂O), waste (CO₂), burning - crop residues (CO₂), and agrifood systems (N₂O). Land management emissions factor encompasses manure management (CO₂), Emissions from livestock (N₂O), and AFOLU (CO₂). The food supply chain emissions factor is linked to food transport (N₂O), pre-and post-production (N₂O), other (CO₂), and net forest conversion (CO₂). These findings align with a literature review report by Chataut, Bhatta51 and Raza, Abid48. These factors are very likely to lead to soil degradation and reduce arable land, coupled with the food waste in the supply chain, which exacerbates food insecurity52,53. Policymakers and stakeholders can now prioritize the variables identified by the extreme gradient boosting and random forest model for the allocation of Africa’s limited resources on targeted mitigation efforts.In many parts of Africa, biomass burning is widespread due to the dominance of subsistence farming and economic limitations that make it a more affordable and accessible option compared to mechanized methods. Rural communities often practice slash-and-burn agriculture to clear land and enhance soil fertility. At the same time, fuelwood and charcoal remain the primary sources of energy for cooking and heating because of limited access to electricity and clean energy alternatives54. The persistence of biomass burning is further exacerbated by weak environmental regulation enforcement, recurring dry seasons, and inadequate waste management infrastructure. Smallholder farmers, already vulnerable to declining soil fertility and unpredictable weather, are frequently caught in a poverty cycle. Biomass burning emissions release significant amounts of CO₂, CH₄, N₂O, and black carbon, which not only contribute to global climate change but also disrupt regional climate systems by influencing rainfall patterns and temperature extremes55. These changes pose direct threats to agricultural productivity and, by extension, food security54,56. Such outcomes hinder progress toward achieving Sustainable Development Goal 2 (Zero Hunger), particularly in regions like Africa, where subsistence agriculture is prevalent and adaptive capacity is limited. Tackling biomass burning emissions through integrated and climate-resilient approaches, such as promoting mulching and agroforestry to reduce dependence on fire-based land clearing, can support efforts toward Zero Hunger (SDG 2) and Climate Action (SDG 13). Additionally, investing in climate-smart initiatives like early warning systems and drought-tolerant crops can strengthen community resilience against the climatic impacts associated with biomass burning and other emission sources must be paramount in Africa.The identified land management emissions highlight the significant impact of agricultural activities, deforestation, and soil degradation, key contributors to greenhouse gas emissions related to land use in Africa. Subsistence farming, which dominates the continent’s land use, often involves large-scale clearing of natural vegetation for crops and livestock, resulting in substantial emissions from land conversion and decomposition of organic matter57. Practices such as continuous monocropping, overgrazing, and the overuse of fertilizers not only degrade soil quality but also lead to the release of nitrous oxide, a highly potent greenhouse gas58. In addition, soil erosion accelerates the loss of carbon stored in terrestrial ecosystems. To offset declining soil fertility, farmers may need to increase their use of fertilizers, raising production costs. This degradation in soil health and productivity ultimately threatens food security and the livelihoods of rural communities. The prominence of land management emissions in Africa highlights the intricate link between agricultural practices, environmental sustainability, and human well-being. Tackling these emissions effectively can aid climate change mitigation and advance progress toward Life on Land (SDG 15) through integrated policy and practical reforms, such as promoting agroecological practices, securing land tenure rights, and enhancing investment in farmer education.The prominence of food supply chain emissions in our findings highlights the increasing environmental burden posed by modern food systems. In many developing countries, inadequate storage and processing infrastructure contribute to significant post-harvest losses, thereby raising the carbon footprint per unit of consumable food. The long-distance transportation of agricultural products, particularly perishable items, further adds to emissions. This issue is exacerbated in parts of Africa and Asia where outdated diesel-powered vehicles and poor road networks are common. At the retail and consumer levels, food waste that ends up in landfills produces methane, a potent greenhouse gas. This challenge is becoming especially critical in urban areas where changing consumption habits and rising waste volumes intensify the problem. Addressing emissions associated with logistics, packaging, and cold storage is essential for meeting both public health and climate goals in Africa. Special attention must be directed toward reducing transport-related air pollution and enhancing food safety standards. These efforts offer valuable opportunities for systemic transformation through improved efficiency and cleaner energy adoption.By integrating Principal Component Analysis (PCA) with advanced machine learning methods, such as Random Forest and Gradient Boosting, the research effectively extracts and assesses the most influential factors from a complex, multidimensional dataset. Through variable importance analysis, the study identifies key emission sources that significantly affect food security. Importantly, this research bridges a crucial gap between empirical greenhouse gas emission data and food security indicators, underscoring the value of data-driven approaches in addressing the interlinked challenges of climate change and hunger. In the African context, the findings reveal that emissions from biomass burning and land-use change, largely driven by subsistence farming, deforestation, and limited uptake of sustainable agricultural practices, are particularly influential. By aligning these findings with global sustainability goals, the study advances progress toward several Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), including SDG 2 (Zero Hunger), SDG 13 (Climate Action), SDG 12 (Responsible Consumption and Production), and SDG 15 (Life on Land). The insights presented serve as a critical resource for policymakers, development agencies, and researchers seeking to craft integrated strategies that simultaneously address climate and food system challenges. Ultimately, this work provides both a methodological model for examining complex climate-food relationships and a practical foundation for fostering adaptive, low-emission food systems in vulnerable regions such as sub-Saharan Africa.Additionally, the PCA-derived components give a structured way to categorize and address emissions sources, such as the reduction in enteric fermentation in livestock and promoting sustainable land use practices accompanied by improving manure management. In developing a climate action plan in connection to food security, the PCA-derived components (e.g., Biomass Burning factor, Livestock and Energy factor, and food supply chain factor) can inform national and regional climate policies by prioritizing sectors with the highest emissions. Our work plays a significant role in the understanding of the greenhouse gas emissions in Africa, which has often been underrepresented concerning climate change in association with food security. The use of PCA and machine learning provides a replicable framework for analyzing complex environmental data.Even though the variable importance score explored in our study provides insights into which variables contribute the most to predictions, it can be biased when variables are highly correlated. Again, our study did not establish a causal relationship between food security and climate change drives. The correlation coefficients employed in naming our component may oversimplify the data, which may lead to potential misinterpretation. Future studies could investigate the use of hybrid models that leverage the complementary strengths of multiple machine learning techniques to improve predictive accuracy. This could be further enhanced by incorporating high-resolution spatial data, analyzing temporal patterns under varying climate scenarios, and integrating socio-economic models to assess the effectiveness of policy measures. Furthermore, conducting regional comparative analyses, including local stakeholder perspectives, and developing real-time monitoring systems could significantly improve the relevance, applicability, and scalability of such research across diverse agro-climatic regions.ConclusionIn our study, we have demonstrated the use of machine learning methods in the identification of key source climate change drivers impacting Africa’s food security, extreme gradient boosting and random were identified as the top performing models, indicative of remarkable identical predictive capabilities. The most important variables common to these models are food house consumption emissions (CH4), food transport emissions(N2O), and burning crop residue emissions(N2O). The PCA-derived components highlighted critical emission sources such as biomass-burning emissions factor, land management emissions factor, and food supply chain emissions factor. The combination of the strong predictive performance models and leveraging PCA for the data highlights key areas for intervention. The findings give a guideline for the efficient allocation of resources to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions, while improving food security, reinforcing the significance of evidence-based approaches to address the dual challenges of climate change and food security.

PONTE SULLO STRETTO DI MESSINA:
NUOVO RECLAMO ALL’UNIONE EUROPEA DI GREENPEACE, LEGAMBIENTE, LIPU E WWF

L’impatto ambientale del Ponte sullo Stretto di Messina è certo, documentato e, dopo anni di negazioni, ammesso dagli stessi proponenti l’opera. Per superare questa impasse è stata avviata una procedura speciale che consentirebbe comunque la realizzazione del Ponte secondo condizioni precise fissate dalle norme comunitarie, condizioni che però non sono state rispettate.  Per questo le Associazioni Greenpeace, Legambiente, Lipu e WWF hanno presentato oggi, 4 agosto, un nuovo reclamo all’Unione Europea ad integrazione di quello già inviato il 27 marzo di quest’anno.

Oggetto del reclamo è il secondo parere della Commissione VIA VAS (n. 72/2025) con cui si è chiusa la cosiddetta procedura di “livello III della VINCA” (Valutazione d’Incidenza), cioè la procedura che si è dovuta obbligatoriamente attivare perché indicata dal primo parere della Commissione VIA VAS (n. 19/2024), che pur rilasciando parere positivo di compatibilità ambientale dell’opera lo ha condizionato a ben 62 prescrizioni (ancora da ottemperare) tra cui, appunto, da questa procedura speciale aggiuntiva.

Se non ci fossero impatti ambientali questa procedura non sarebbe mai stata avviata. Questa, infatti, si attiva solo in presenza di impatti ambientali acclarati e non mitigabili che riguardano aree tutelate dalle direttive comunitarie Habitat ed Uccelli, cioè i siti della Rete Natura 2000, che interessano anche lo stretto di Messina, sia il lato siciliano che quello calabrese oltre che il tratto di mare che li separa. La Commissione VIA VAS ha evidenziato gli impatti ambientali che il Ponte produrrebbe e, quindi, per poter procedere all’autorizzazione del progetto nonostante questo incida sui siti Natura 2000, ha prescritto la procedura di autorizzazione in deroga che però prevede tre condizioni ineludibili: l’assenza di alternative rispetto al progetto che produce impatti, la presenza di motivi imperativi di rilevante interesse pubblico che lo giustifichino, e interventi ambientali compensativi che bilancino gli impatti che provoca. Secondo Greenpeace, Legambiente, Lipu e WWF tali condizioni non sussistono. Inoltre, il modo in cui si è tentato di dimostrare la sussistenza di questi requisiti è stato strumentale per eludere il parere che altrimenti si darebbe dovuto chiedere all’Unione Europea. Infatti, il Governo nei motivi imperativi di rilevante interesse pubblico, oltre a valutazioni economiche sul rapporto costi benefici dell’opera, ampliamente opinabili, ed oltre ad effetto economico atteso dal carattere miracolistico, ha sostenuto che il Ponte avrebbe un interesse strategico anche per motivi di sicurezza militare, sanitaria e di protezione civile e in presenza di tali motivazioni la procedura viene esentata dal parere comunitario.

.     Ma le motivazioni militari sono paradossali non fosse perché il Ponte se militarmente strategico sarebbe il primo obiettivo da abbattere, per non dire che pensare oggi a spostamenti rapidi di mezzi e truppe via terra ha dell’anacronistico. Le motivazioni di protezione civile, richiamate sia in caso di calamità sia per gli incendi, non tengono correttamente conto dei mezzi e delle persone dislocate sul territorio, non considerano il collasso del sistema di mobilità che ci sarebbe in caso di terremoto, fingono d’ignorare il sistema di dislocamento dei canadair e la gestione nazionale di questi. Le motivazioni sanitarie addirittura sostengono l’inverosimile tesi per cui il Ponte migliorerebbe l’accesso ai servizi sanitari, si favorirebbe il coordinamento dei centri di cura, si ridurrebbe il sovraccarico ospedaliero, si migliorerebbero i servizi sanitari nel loro complesso, quando i sistemi di sanitari di Messina, Villa San Giovanni e Reggio hanno problemi di mezzi e risorse che nulla c’entrano con l’attraversamento dello Stretto.

La Commissione VIA VAS, ritenendo competenza del Governo la dichiarazione dei motivi imperativi di rilevante interesse pubblico, non è entrata nel merito delle questioni e sostanzialmente ha fatto una mera presa d’atto. Non altrettanto potrà fare l’Unione Europea perché ciò significherebbe eludere i principi del trattato dell’Unione Europea e delle direttive ambientali.

La Commissione VIA VAS sembra poi non aver ritenuto di propria competenza l’analisi delle alternative, limitandosi a ratificare le analisi svolte dai proponenti e dal Governo. La soluzione a campata unica è stata infatti scelta nel 2023 da una legge ad hoc approvata dal Parlamento con voto di fiducia. Si già eccepito in sede di ricorso al TAR questo approccio di carattere notarile della Commissione VIA VAS, ma anche laddove si ritenesse questo legittimo varrebbe solo in assenza di impatti ambientali. Per non violare le direttive comunitarie ambientali, sovraordinate rispetto la normativa nazionale, è evidente che l’analisi delle alternative non è stata svolta nei termini indicati dalle direttive europee. Sul punto il Governo ha sostenuto le tesi dei proponenti l’opera, non ha dunque avuto un approccio di terzietà, per una valutazione oggettiva. Non a caso il Gruppo di Lavoro nominato sul tema dal Governo Draghi, formato in gran parte da valenti tecnici di Enti pubblici, solo qualche anno fa nel 2021 era ufficialmente arrivato a conclusioni diverse che non sono state oggetto neppure di controdeduzioni.

Le compensazioni proposte sono gravemente insufficienti.  La carenza di analisi naturalistiche su cui si basa è acclarata perché oggetto di prescrizioni della Commissione VIA VAS non ancora ottemperate e le misure proposte sono limitate oltre che di dubbia efficacia.  Siamo di fronte a monitoraggi inadeguati. Ad esempio, per la stima delle incidenze sull’avifauna migratrice sono stati strumentalmente usati dati non aggiornati, raccolti nel 2011 nell’ambito della precedente procedura VIA VINCA. È inoltre sottostimata la perdita di habitat di specie avifaunistiche, nonché le incidenze derivanti dalle modifiche ambientali a cui è sottoposta tutta l’area, in fase di cantiere e di esercizio. Non è poi stato considerato l’effetto sinergico e cumulativo generato dalle diverse opere che compongono il progetto, né sono stati valutati gli effetti cumulativi con altri piani e progetti già programmati. A mero titolo d’esempio, ma altri se ne potrebbero fare, la reale efficacia delle misure di mitigazione per l’avifauna migratrice non è comprovata. A sostegno di questo si ricorda quanto dichiarato dall’Istituto Superiore per Protezione e la Ricerca Ambientale (ISPRA) ed acquisito dalla Commissione VIA VAS nel lavoro istruttorio senza però essere stato debitamente considerato: “L’impatto diretto e indiretto causato dal collegamento tra le due sponde e da tutte le infrastrutture ad esso collegato compresa l’enorme attività cantieristica per alcuni taxa (cioè alcune categorie di specie) in stato di conservazione sfavorevole o a rischio di estinzione non è mitigabile né compensabile”.

Le Associazioni Greenpeace, Legambiente, Lipu e WWF ritengono che nessuno dei criteri obbligatori previsti dalla procedura comunitaria sia stato correttamente rispettato; pertanto, ritengono che l’Italia stia violando le disposizioni di cui alle Direttive 92/43/CEE “Habitat” e 2009/147/CE “Uccelli”. Da qui il nuovo reclamo oggi presentato ad integrazione a quello già inviato il 27 marzo di quest’anno, chiedendo l’apertura di una procedura di infrazione.

Le torri di Inwit protagoniste della lotta agli incendi. Al via il nuovo progetto in partnership con Legambiente per la prevenzione e il monitoraggio degli incendi con l’intelligenza artificiale nella Riserva naturale di Monte Mario e nel Parco urbano del Pineto a Roma.

Un patrimonio verde secolare incastonato nella Capitale quello della Riserva Naturale di Monte Mario e del Parco Urbano del Pineto, che si estende per circa 500 ettari, tanto quanto 700 campi da calcio e che, puntualmente, ogni estate rischia di andare in fumo a causa di rovinosi incendi. A tutela di questo inestimabile polmone verde, gestito dall’Ente Regionale RomaNatura, prende avvio un progetto innovativo tra INWIT, primo tower operator italiano e tra le principali digital infrastructure company, e Legambiente.
Su 5 torri di telecomunicazione di INWIT presenti a ridosso della Riserva Naturale di Monte Mario e del Parco Urbano del Pineto sono state installate 6 videocamere smart e 5 gateway, dotati di AI, in grado di rilevare tempestivamente pennacchi di fumo e principi di incendio.

La localizzazione di queste nuove tecnologie sulla sommità delle torri, a supporto del prezioso lavoro delle Forze dell’ordine e della Protezione Civile, garantisce una posizione privilegiata, che consente di massimizzare l’area sotto osservazione. La distanza massima che le telecamere possono coprire varia a seconda delle caratteristiche orografiche del luogo e delle dimensioni relative del pennacchio di incendio. La distanza di osservazione è mediamente di 2,5 km dal punto di monitoraggio, ma in determinati casi è possibile individuare pennacchi di fumo fino a 5 km. Le apparecchiature sono in grado di funzionare anche in condizioni ambientali difficili e, grazie all’intelligenza artificiale, di distinguere il fumo dei camini o di un barbecue da quello degli incendi.

Questo progetto si inserisce in una partnership tra INWIT e Legambiente per il monitoraggio e la prevenzione degli incendi e per il monitoraggio della qualità dell’aria. Nel 2023 è stata avviata l’attività di monitoraggio dei parametri di inquinamento atmosferico con sensori IoT e gateway in 5 aree naturali dell’Appennino centrale (Parco Nazionale Abruzzo, Lazio e Molise, Parco Nazionale della Maiella, Riserva Naturale Zompo lo Schioppo, Riserva Naturale Monte Genzana Alto Gizio e Riserva Naturale Regionale Punta Aderci) e nel luglio 2024 quella relativa alla prevenzione degli incendi boschivi con videocamere smart e gateway in 6 territori (Pescasseroli -AQ, nel cuore del Parco Nazionale d’Abruzzo, Lazio e Molise, Pettorano sul Gizio -AQ, Riserva Naturale Regionale Monte Genzana Alto Gizio, Riserva Naturale Regionale Lecceta di Torino di Sangro -CH, Riserva Naturale Bosco Don Venanzio a Pollutri –CH, e Civitella Roveto -AQ, per monitorare l’area della Longagna). Complessivamente sono così 13 le torri di INWIT presenti in questi territori sulle quali sono stati installati 13 gateway, 6 sensori IoT per il monitoraggio della qualità dell’aria e 15 telecamere integrate con un software di intelligenza artificiale in grado di rilevare tempestivamente gli incendi.

“Le nostre infrastrutture digitali sono alleate del territorio nella tutela della biodiversità e dell’ambiente. L’installazione sulle nostre torri di videocamere intelligenti e gateway con AI, infatti, conferma il valore strategico delle nostre infrastrutture: oltre ad abilitare la connettività mobile multi-operatore possono essere protagoniste di attività di monitoraggio del territorio e ambientale anche per prevenire gli incendi”, ha commentato Michelangelo Suigo Direttore Relazioni Esterne, Comunicazione & Sostenibilità di INWIT.

“Dopo il progetto di prevenzione e monitoraggio incendi avviato la scorsa estate in Abruzzo, ora con INWIT ci spostiamo nella Capitale – commenta Giorgio Zampetti Direttore Generale di Legambiente – Per vigilare sulla Riserva Naturale di Monte Mario e il Parco Urbano del Pineto, due luoghi simbolo di Roma da sempre cari a cittadini e turisti, oltre che patrimonio di biodiversità prezioso e strategico per la città. Purtroppo, il rischio incendi anche per i parchi e le aree verdi urbane è sempre più alto. A luglio 2024 un vasto incendio ha distrutto una parte di Monte Mario, una ferita ancora visibile oggi, che ci ricorda l’urgenza di investire nella prevenzione incendi e di prevedere maggiori risorse per il verde urbano. Una prevenzione che si può portare avanti anche con l’aiuto della tecnologia e dell’intelligenza artificiale come dimostra l’attività che stiamo portando avanti con INWIT”.
“Siamo favorevoli all’introduzione di innovazioni tecnologiche che possano contribuire in modo concreto alla tutela del patrimonio naturale. Le attività previste si integrano pienamente con le azioni già in corso da parte di RomaNatura per la prevenzione degli incendi boschivi, nel solco delle attività pianificate e operative già adottate dall’Ente”, lo dichiara il Direttore dell’Ente Regionale RomaNatura Emiliano Manari.

Nel Lazio, da inizio anno al 18 luglio 2025, secondo l’ultimo report diffuso in questi giorni da Legambiente, sono bruciati 696 ettari con 28 incendi. E per quanto riguarda le aree Natura 2000, il Lazio conta 279,44 ettari percorsi dal fuoco con 13 incendi.

items.description: Flash mob sull’Adamello che ospita il ghiacciaio più grande delle Alpi italiane. Il gigante bianco nel 2024 ha registrato un arretramento della front
items.body:
3 Agosto 2025
